symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain along with fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It could manifest as chronic back pain and can coexist with conditions like GERD and cognitive disturbances similar to attention deficits.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.rationale: Glycemic lability strongly suggests this diagnosis. Diabetes can also contribute to conditions such as gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and may indirectly affect attention through variations in blood glucose levels. Neuropathy could also manifest as chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition is characterized by extreme, long-lasting fatigue that isn't relieved by rest. Chronic pain, cognitive difficulties, and digestive complaints are common. It might not directly explain glycemic lability but can co-occur with conditions that do.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.rationale: Directly indicated by the presence of gastroesophageal reflux symptoms. It's included due to its significant impact on quality of life and potential association with respiratory symptoms (e.g., dyspnea) through aspiration or reflex mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Can manifest with a broad range of physical symptoms, including gastrointestinal issues (like GERD), chronic pain, variations in glucose levels, and difficulty concentrating, which could align with the symptom of attention deficit.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.rationale: May manifest not only with affective symptoms but also physical complaints including chronic pain, digestive issues, cognitive disturbances (attention difficulties), and changes in appetite that might influence glycemic control.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.rationale: While normal pulmonary function tests may seem contradictory, asthma can present with dyspnea and normal test results outside of an acute attack. It doesn't directly explain the other symptoms but can coexist with conditions like GERD.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.rationale: Both hypothyroidism and hyperthyroidism can explain a subset of symptoms like attention deficits, dyspnea, and glycemic lability. They can also contribute to mood disturbances and digestive problems.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., lupus, rheumatoid arthritis)
diagnoses.rationale: These conditions can present with a wide variety of symptoms including chronic pain, dyspnea, and gastroesophageal reflux. They can also involve cognitive issues and affect glucose metabolism indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for causing sleep disturbances, it can also lead to daytime fatigue, attention deficits, and indirectly, through mechanisms of disrupted sleep and hypoxia, influence metabolic regulation and potentially contribute to symptoms like glycemic lability.

diagnoses: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD) with comorbid Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)

diagnoses.name: Behçet's disease
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting multiple parts of the body, including the eyes, blood vessels, mucous membranes, and often leading to vascular issues like aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the glands responsible for tears and saliva, causing dry eyes and mouth, and can also lead to systemic complications.

diagnoses.name: Marfan syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the connective tissue, leading to cardiovascular, ocular, and skeletal manifestations, including a predisposition to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disease that causes inflammation of the blood vessels in the nose, sinuses, throat, lungs, and kidneys, potentially leading to bronchitis and aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders affecting connective tissues, known for hypermobility, skin elasticity, and vulnerability to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease causing the small and medium-sized arteries to become swollen and damaged, potentially leading to aneurysms.

diagnoses.name: Churg-Strauss syndrome
diagnoses.description: Also known as eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, it's a disorder marked by inflammation of blood vessels and can affect various organs including the lungs.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body, mostly affecting children. It can lead to aneurysms in coronary arteries.

diagnoses.name: Loeys-Dietz syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder affecting connective tissue, characterized by the widespread arterial aneurysms and tortuosity, hypertelorism, and bifid uvula or cleft palate.

diagnoses.name: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory lung disease that causes obstructed airflow from the lungs. Symptoms include breathing difficulty, cough, mucus (sputum) production, and wheezing. It's caused by long-term exposure to irritating gases or particulate matter, most often from cigarette smoke. People with COPD are at increased risk of developing heart disease, lung cancer, and a variety of other conditions.

diagnoses: Immunodeficiency Disorders, such as Common Variable Immunodeficiency

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (including Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can cause severe throbbing pain or a pulsing sensation, usually on one side of the head. It's often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine attacks can cause significant pain for hours to days and can be so severe that the pain is disabling.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body. Symptoms include numbness or weakness in one or more limbs, typically on one side of your body at a time, or the legs and trunk.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. Symptoms include trouble speaking and understanding what others are saying, paralysis or numbness of the face, arm or leg.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It's caused by a decrease in blood supply to part of the brain, which may result in a sudden but temporary weakness or numbness in the arms, legs, or face, especially on one side of the body, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Cervical Spondylosis
diagnoses.details: This condition involves changes to the bones, discs, and joints of the neck caused by aging and wear and tear. Symptoms include pain and stiffness around the neck, numbness and weakness in arms, hands, and fingers, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: Peripheral neuropathy results from damage to the peripheral nerves and causes weakness, numbness, and pain, typically in the hands and feet. It can also affect other areas and functions of the body, including digestion, urination, and circulation.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Symptoms can include headaches that are typically worse in the morning, seizures, personality or memory changes, nausea or vomiting, fatigue, and numbness or weakness of part of the body.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.details: Guillain-Barre Syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.details: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. The condition can lead to numbness, weakness, and pain, especially in the hands and feet. It can also affect other body parts and functions, including digestion and heart rate.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.details: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck. It can be life-threatening and requires immediate medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: Migraines with aura are a type of migraine that involves visual disturbances such as scotomas. Other symptoms can include headache, nausea, and light sensitivity.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Brain tumors can press on nerve cells in the brain, causing symptoms such as headaches, speech problems, and weakness on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief, temporary disruption of blood flow to part of the brain, which can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, including aphasia, weakness, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: MS is a disease of the central nervous system that disrupts the flow of information within the brain and between the brain and body. It can cause symptoms such as numbness, weakness, balance issues, and speech disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: Epilepsy is a central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Some types of epilepsy can cause aphasia as part of the seizure activity.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Symptoms can include headache, weakness, speech problems, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the membranes around the brain and spinal cord. It can be caused by bacteria, viruses, or other microorganisms. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck, along with neurological deficits such as weakness.

diagnoses.name: Primary CNS Vasculitis
diagnoses.description: Primary CNS vasculitis is inflammation of blood vessel walls in the brain and spinal cord. It can cause headaches, neurological deficits, including weakness and speech difficulties, and other symptoms depending on the areas of the CNS affected.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Hemorrhagic stroke occurs when a blood vessel in the brain leaks or ruptures. Besides the common stroke symptoms like weakness and speech difficulties, it may also be accompanied by severe headaches.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Schizophrenia (in the context of autoimmune disorders can manifest as psychosis)
Thyroid Disorders (e.g., Hashimoto's Thyroiditis can rarely lead to psychosis)
